title: Data domain segmentation for SACM
content:
Data domain segmentation in Service Management provides the ability to restrict the visibility of specific records and actions to specific people, roles, or groups.

Data domain segmentation is supported for the following record types:

  • Operational data record types: Approval, Article, Change, Incident, Problem, Request, Service Level Target (SLT), Task, Device, System Element, Service Component, Actual Service, and Infrastructure & Peripherals.
  • Reference data record types: Location, Person, Company, Group, Record Category, and Contract

For more information about managing the data domain list, assigning data domain permissions, and assigning a record to a data domain, see Data domain segmentation.

Among these operational data record types, Device, System Element, Service Component, Actual Service, and Infrastructure & Peripherals are supported SACM record types. This topic gives examples of how data domain segmentation works for the SACM module. 

Data domain segmentation supports the Service Management-UCMDB integration through either OPB or the Native SACM solution.

  • For more information about OPB configurations, see the Customize an existing mapping file section of How to tailor custom synchronization through OPB.  
  • For more information about Native SACM, see Native SACM.

General use of data domain segmentation for SACM

Grid, report, and global search

Users with the Tenant Admin role are authorized for all data domains. Common SACM users only have access to records within their data domains.

Consider the following scenario:

  • The Primary domain of UserA is set to IT.
  • You have the following Device records with specific data domains:
    • Device1: IT
    • Device2: HR
    • Device3: Finance

In this scenario:

  • When UserA views the Devices grid, only Device1 is visible.
  • When UserA views a report of Devices, only Device1 is included.
  • When UserA uses global search, even if Device1, Device2, and Device3 all match the search criteria, only Device1 is presented as the result.

Data domain segmentation for automatic CI recognition

In rich text fields, Service Management enables automatic recognition of CIs. This feature allows for rapid accurate identification of affected CIs. For more information about this feature, see Automatic recognition of CIs.

Data domain segmentation also applies to this automatic CI recognition.

Consider the following scenario:

  • The Primary domain of UserA is set to IT.
  • You have the following Device records with specific data domains:
    • SERV23SD162: IT
    • SERV23SD117: IT
    • DB02NY149: Finance

In this scenario:

When UserA goes to a service request that has these three devices in its description, only the devices within his/her data domain (IT) are recognized, as shown below.
 

In addition, only SERV23SD162 and SERV23SD117 are automatically added to the Involved CIs tab of this service request.

Data domain segmentation for Involved CIs 

In Change, Problem, Incident, and Service Request records, you can add or remove Device, Infrastructure & Peripheral, System Element, and Actual Service records on the Involved CIs tab. Data domain segmentation also applies here. That is, if the currently logged-in user doesn't have access to some CIs' data domains, these CI records are hidden from the user.

Consider the following scenario:

  • The Primary domain of UserA is set to IT.
  • You have the following Device records with specific data domains:
    • Device1: IT
    • Device2: HR
  • You have the following Service Request record:
    • Request1 has Device1 and Device2 as Involved devices.
    • Request1's Data Domain is set to IT.

In this scenario:

  • When UserA goes to the Involved CIs tab of Request1, UserA only sees Device1 listed as in the Involved devices list.

Data domain segmentation for Impact Analysis

Data domain segmentation also applies to the impact map. That is, if the currently logged-in user doesn't have access to some impacted records' data domains, these records aren't available on the impact map.  

Data domain segmentation takes effect in both standalone Service Management and Native-SACM-enabled environments. Although the widgets have different appearances, the logged-in user only sees the items he/she is supposed to see.

Consider the following scenario:

  • The Primary domain of UserA is set to IT.
  • You have the following System Element records with specific data domains:
    • SE1: IT
    • SE2: IT
    • SE3: HR
  • You have the following Device record:
    • Device1 has SE1, SE2, and SE3 as Impacted CIs.

In this scenario:

  • When a Tenant Admin clicks the Show Impact button of Device1, he/she can see all SE1, SE2, and SE3 on the impact map.
  • When UserA clicks the Show Impact button of Device1, he/she can see all SE1 and SE2 on the impact map.

In addition, the Show Impact feature on the Involved CIs tab of Change, Problem, Incident, and Service Request records also supports data domain segmentation.

Data domain segmentation in a Native-SACM-enabled environment

If you have enabled data domain segmentation for Native SACM. For a federated SACM record (Actual Service, Device, Service Component, or System Element), its data domain and the UCMDB consumer tenant of the CI are synchronized. Generally, it works with the following rules:

  • When a federated SACM record is created with a data domain, a CI is created in UCMDB with the same UCMDB consumer tenant.
  • Similarly, when a federated CI is created in UCMDB with a UCMDB consumer tenant, a SACM record is created with the same data domain.
  • When working in a UCMDB multi-tenancy environment, it's often necessary to apply the same tenancy definitions to many CIs. A convenient way to do this is by using Tenant Association rules, which are a form of Enrichment rules. An admin defines Tenant Association rules in the Enrichment Manager in the same way of defining Enrichment rules. A common usage of Tenant Association rules is to allow proper consumer tenants to be assigned to physical CIs discovered by UD. For details, see Tenant Association Rules (Classic UD/UCMDB) or Tenant Association Rules (Containerized UD/UCMDB).
  • If you change either the data domain of a SACM record or the UCMDB consumer tenant of a CI, the change will be synchronized to the other system.
  • As recommended in Enable data domain segmentation for Native SACM, all Service Management data domains and UCMDB consumer tenants are supposed to be mapped. In case a UCMDB tenant doesn't have a corresponding data domain in Service Management, any CIs created in it will not be synchronized to Service Management.
  • Data domains can be disabled in Service Management, while UCMDB consumer tenants can't. After you disable a data domain in Service Management, new records can no longer be created with this data domain, however, this data domain still takes effect for existing records, you will observe a strikethrough over the data domain value. As a UCMDB tenant can't be disabled, even if you disable the corresponding data domain in Service Management, you still can create new CIs with this tenant. The newly created CIs will still be synchronized to Service Management with the data domain that has been disabled. Likewise, you will see a strikethrough over the data domain value. 
  • In CI topology widgets such as Related CIs and Show Impact, the logged-in agent only sees the items belonging to the data domains that he/she has access to. 

Consider the following scenario:

  • Native SACM and UCMDB multi-tenancy are enabled. Service Management data domains and UCMDB consumer tenants are synchronized.  
  • The Primary domain of UserA is set to IT1.
  • You have the following Device records with specific data domains:
    • Device1: IT1
    • Device2: IT2
    • Device3: Finance
  • Because data domain segmentation is enabled for Native SACM, the following Nodes in UCMDB are with the corresponding UCMDB consumer tenants:
    • Device1: IT1
    • Device2: IT2
    • Device3: Finance

In this scenario:

  • When UserA views the Devices grid, only Device1 is visible.
  • With Shared IdM and SSO configured, when UserA opens the UCMDB browser, User1 automatically gets signed in.
  • If you have configured UCMDB user permissions as described in User Permissions in a Multi-Tenancy Environment, UserA only sees Device1 in Nodes.
  • When the Service Management tenant admin changes the data domain of Device2 to IT1, the UCMDB consumer tenant of Device2 node becomes IT1, and UserA has access to Device2 in both Service Management and UCMDB.
